source.53f909c4:
# Install the required packages
install.packages("tidyverse")    # used for manipulation and visualization the data
install.packages("sqldf")        # manipulate R Data Frames using SQL
install.packages("lubridate")    # To work with date and time data
install.packages("skimr")        # used for summarizing the data
install.packages("janitor")      # used for cleaning the data

# Load the packages
library(tidyverse)
library(sqldf)
library(lubridate)
library(skimr)
library(janitor)

# Uploading the 12 months datasets
Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1 <- read_csv("cyclistic/2019/Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1.csv")
Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2 <- read_csv("cyclistic/2019/Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2.csv")
Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3 <- read_csv("cyclistic/2019/Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3.csv")
Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4 <- read_csv("cyclistic/2019/Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4.csv")
source.103bb999:
# Inspecting the uploaded datasets
str(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1)
str(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2)
str(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3)
str(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4)

colnames(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1)
colnames(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2)
colnames(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3)
colnames(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4)

glimpse(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1)
glimpse(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2)
glimpse(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3)
glimpse(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4)
source.7dd3f37d:
# rename colname in dataset Q2
Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2 <- Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2 %>% 
  rename(trip_id = '01 - Rental Details Rental ID',
         start_time = '01 - Rental Details Local Start Time',
         end_time = '01 - Rental Details Local End Time',
         bikeid = '01 - Rental Details Bike ID',
         tripduration = '01 - Rental Details Duration In Seconds Uncapped',
         from_station_id = '03 - Rental Start Station ID',
         from_station_name = '03 - Rental Start Station Name',
         to_station_id = '02 - Rental End Station ID',
         to_station_name = '02 - Rental End Station Name',
         usertype = 'User Type',
         gender = 'Member Gender',
         birthyear = '05 - Member Details Member Birthday Year')
source.2f541ea8:
# Inspecting dataset after renaming the matching columns
glimpse(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2)
head(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2)
source.e6f69587:
# Converting Data Type
Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1 <- mutate(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1, trip_id = as.character(trip_id),
                              bikeid = as.character(bikeid),
                              from_station_id = as.character(from_station_id),
                              to_station_id = as.character(to_station_id))

Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2 <- mutate(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2, trip_id = as.character(trip_id),
                              bikeid = as.character(bikeid),
                              from_station_id = as.character(from_station_id),
                              to_station_id = as.character(to_station_id))

Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3 <- mutate(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3, trip_id = as.character(trip_id),
                              bikeid = as.character(bikeid),
                              from_station_id = as.character(from_station_id),
                              to_station_id = as.character(to_station_id))

Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4 <- mutate(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4, trip_id = as.character(trip_id),
                              bikeid = as.character(bikeid),
                              from_station_id = as.character(from_station_id),
                              to_station_id = as.character(to_station_id))
source.39669585:
# Merge All Dataset
cyclistic_2019 <- bind_rows(Divvy_Trips_2019_Q1, Divvy_Trips_2019_Q2, 
                       Divvy_Trips_2019_Q3, Divvy_Trips_2019_Q4)

str(cyclistic_2019)
glimpse(cyclistic_2019)
head(cyclistic_2019)
source.7b461f3d:
# Adding column ride_length
cyclistic_2019$ride_length <- round(difftime(cyclistic_2019$end_time, cyclistic_2019$start_time),0)
cyclistic_2019$ride_length <- as.numeric(cyclistic_2019$ride_length)
source.23ee1558:
# Checklist for possible errors in the dataset 
n_unique(cyclistic_2019$trip_id)
sum(duplicated(cyclistic_2019))
summary(cyclistic_2019)
colSums(is.na(cyclistic_2019))
source.039840cd:
# Remove column tripduration, gender, birthyear
cyclistic_2019 <- cyclistic_2019 %>% 
  select(-c(tripduration, gender, birthyear))
source.52ba185f: ## ** Prepare Phase ** * ** ### **Basic understanding of data collection** * Data Source: [Source of data](https://divvy-tripdata.s3.amazonaws.com/index.html). * It is a structured data * Data Period: Previous 12 months (2019) of Cyclistic trip data available at Motivate International Inc. and number of files and variables; + 13 csv. files + 13 variables The datasets used in this analysis have been made available by Motivate Internation Inc. under this [license](https://www.divvybikes.com/data-license-agreement). This is public data that you can use to explore how different customer types are using Cyclistic bikes. But note that data-privacy issues prohibit us from using riders’ personally identifiable information. This means that we won’t be able to connect pass purchases to credit card numbers to determine if casual riders live in the Cyclistic service area or if they have purchased multiple single passes. ### **Defining the bias or credibility of data through ROCCC Analysis** - **Reliable** - yes, not biased, not sure if the data is vetted. - **Original** - yes, can locate the original public data - **Comprehensive** - No, missing important information such as gender, age, NA values, pricings, incorrect dates, duplicates with incorrect dates - **Current** - not, but historical and updated monthly - **Cited** - yes
source.72c20b6a: # ** Cyclistic: Bike-Share Company** * **Author: Achmad H. Shadiqin** * **Created: 11/11/2021** * **
source.3332fcb4: ## ** Introduction ** * ** ### **Overview** This analysis is intended for the Capstone project to get a Google Data Analytics certificate. **Cyclistic**, is a fictional company that provides bicycle rental services in the Chicago area. Its aim is to analyze how casual and annual riders use bicycle sharing differently. By completing this analysis, it can help marketing strategies for the future. Initially, one approach that company applied that helped make things possible was the flexibility of its pricing plans such as; * **Single ride passes** * **Full-day passes** * **Annual memberships** One thing that informed the marketing team was annual members are more profitable than casual riders. Although, the flexibility of its pricing attract more customers and while keeping this mind, primary stakeholders believe that maximizing the annual members will be the to key-factor to growth in the future and they want casual riders to be converted into the annual members rathan creating a marketing campaign. ### **Business Tasks** The goal of this project is to utilise the existing historical public data and form marketing strategies aimed at converting casual riders in the annual riders. In order to do that, marketing needs to evaluate how casual and annual riders differ, why casual riders would probably buy annual memberships, and how digital media could affect their marketing tactics. * **How do annual members and casual riders use Cyclistic bikes differently?** * **Why would casual riders buy cyclistic annual memberships?** * **How can Cyclistic use digital media platforms to influence casual riders to become annual members?**
source.c642f5e6: ## ** Ask Phase ** * ** In this phase, understanding the problem statement and context, aliging a right set of questions with the business objective, keeping audience expectations in the flow, and continued focus on collaboration with stakeholders and keep an open line of communication is the first step of analysis. In this project, we will go through the business stated above and find out the key findings that will help us give the applicable recommendations to the team. It is quite important to understand your stakeholders and their expectations. Understanding what your stakeholders want and what thier expectations are, help you to set the business tasks and its outcome. Here in this case, just say; **Primary Stakeholder:** * Cyclistic's Director: **Moreno** * Other primary stakeholders: **Executive team** **Secondary Stakeholder:** * Cyclistic's Marketing analytics team Business tasks that we will complete are given below; * **How do annual members and casual riders use Cyclistic bikes differently ?** * **Why would casual riders buy cyclistic annual memberships ?** * **How can Cyclistic use digital media platforms to influence casual riders to become annual members ?**
